Query.SqlString: SELECT Top 32767 ID,Literature FROM Literature WHERE (Literature ='LMCR93')

BibliographicData.Title: Corticocortical connections of area F3 (SMA-proper) and area F6 (Pre-SMA) in the macaque monkey

Reference.Quotation: "Figure 3 illustrates the pattern of retrograde cortical connections following injection in the rostral part of F3 (arm field)." (p. 118)

Reference.Comments: In contrast to the statement in the text (p. 120: "The rostral part of area 24d, from which leg movements are evoked, is completely devoid of labelling."), Figure 3 does show label in the rostral parts of area 24d.
The following description probably refers to area PS82-POa: "... no labelling is observed in the lateral bank of the intraparietal sulcus and the adjacent convexity ... " (p. 125)

Reference.Quotation: "The corticocortical connections of F6 were studied in three cases ... The connection pattern following the rostral injection (case 4l) is shown in Figure 12." (p. 125)
Reference.Comments: Table 1 shows that this injection affected the arm representation in area F6.

Reference.Quotation: "Figure 5 illustrates the pattern of retrograde cortical connections following injection of the caudal part of F3 (leg field)." (p. 120)

Reference.Comments: The following description probably refers to area PS82-PEA: "A few, sparse cells were found in the medial bank of the intraparietal sulcus." (p. 123)
The following description probably refers to area PS82-POa: "... no labelling is observed in the lateral bank of the intraparietal sulcus and the adjacent convexity ... " (p. 125)

Reference.Quotation: "Distribution of retrogradely lablled cells in area 24d following two tracer injections (FG, open circles and TB, filled circles) in the leg field of F1 in case 4r." (legend to Fig. 9C)
"Figure 15 shows another case (case 1) in which the tracer was injected in the caudal part of F6. The injection was smaller than in case 4r and largely restricted to the cortical crown." (p. 128)
Reference.Comments: Table 1 shows that this injection affected that subfield of F6 which represents axial movements.

Reference.Quotation: "Figure 14 illustrates the pattern of retrograde cortical connections following tracer injection in the caudal part of F6 (case 4r)." (p. 125)
Reference.Comments: Table 1 shows that this injection affected the arm representation in area F6.

Reference.Quotation: "Distribution of retrogradely labelled cells in area 24d following tracer injections in the arm field of F1 in two animals (case 6, WGA-HRP, open circles, and case 8, FB, filled circles)." (legend to Fig. 9B)

TracerSubstance.FullName: Horseradish peroxidase, conjugated to wheat germ agglutinin

Reference.Quotation: "Figure 6 shows the cortical areas labelled after injection of the dorsal part of F3. In this case, although the injection site was large and not circumscribed to a single physiological field, the results of microstimulation and the comparison with somatotopic maps suggest that the injection mostly involved the cortex controlling axial movements." (p. 120)

"The injection site in case 3 (Fig. 8) is located at the center of F3 and invades its dorsal and mesial cortical surfaces. Physiologically, the injection corresponds to the axial and arm movement representation of F3." (pp. 120-121)

"...injections of WGA-HRP in different somatotopic fields of F1 in three animals ... Open circles represent the labelling following injection in the leg representation [of F1] (case 5) ..." (legend to Fig. 9A)

"...injections of WGA-HRP in different somatotopic fields of F1 in three animals ... filled circles represent the labelling following injection in the arm representation [of F1] (case 6) ..." (legend to Fig. 9A)

"...injections of WGA-HRP in different somatotopic fields of F1 in three animals ... triangles show the labelling following injection in the face representation [of F1] (case 7) ..." (legend to Fig. 9A)
"Distribution of retrogradely lablled cells in area 24d following two tracer injections (FG, open circles and TB, filled circles) in the leg field of F1 in case 4r." (legend to Fig. 9C)
